entry.et: Middle English, from Old English lōcian; akin to Old Saxon lōcōn to look

def.dt: :to make sure or take care (that something is done)
:to ascertain by the use of one's eyes look what I brought you
:to exercise the power of vision upon :examine
:to search for
:expect anticipate we look to have a good year
:to have in mind as an end looking to win back some lost profits
:to bring into a place or condition by the exercise of the power of vision
:to express by the eyes or facial expression
:to have an appearance that befits or accords with looks her age
:to exercise the power of vision :see
:to direct one's attention look upon the future with hope look at the map
:to direct the eyes looked up from the newspaper
:to have the appearance or likelihood of being :seem it looks unlikely looks to be hard work
:to have a specified outlook the house looked east
:to gaze in wonder or surprise :stare
:to show a tendency the evidence looks to acquittal
:to take care of
:consider 1 looking at the possibility of relocating
:confront face looking at a mandatory fine Cindy Kilass
:to view something with arrogance, disdain, or disapproval
:to await with hope or anticipation
:to search for :seek looking for a new car
:to anticipate with pleasure or satisfaction looking forward to your visit
:explore 1a
:to direct one's attention away from something unpleasant or troublesome
:to direct one's attention to looking to the future
:to rely upon looks to reading for relaxation
:the act of looking
:glance
:the expression of the countenance
:physical appearance
:attractive physical appearance usually used in plural
:a combination of design features giving a unified appearance a new look in women's fashions
:the state or form in which something appears
:one that looks like another :double
:to be in a position that affords a downward view
:to regard with contempt :despise used with on or upon
:a chance of success
:a quick pass in football to a receiver running diagonally toward the center of the field
:watch 3b looked on anxiously from the sidelines
:to take care or concern oneself used with for looking out for number one
:to inspect or examine especially in a cursory way
:a general survey :evaluation inspection
:to cheer up look up—things are not all bad
:to improve in prospects or conditions business is looking up
:to search for in or as if in a reference work look up an address
:to seek out especially for a brief visit look me up when you're here
